Triggering Event: He stepped into his once-shared studio, now his alone since the divorce. There, amidst the dusty canvases and faded paint tubes, was a canvas bearing her favorite piece he'd thought lost. His hand trembled as he picked it up, seeing not the vibrant colors but her mocking smile, hearing not the silence but her voice echoing, "You'll never be more than this, old man." Hatred boiled within him like a long-simmered poison.

Maybe they’re saying, “Hey, remember when we used to have fun painting together? Remember those times when life wasn’t so serious?” Nah, doesn’t matter. Triggering Event: A middle-aged woman, her hands trembling slightly as she tidies the display at work, feels her heart pound as she notices the store manager approaching. She hasn't finished the task yet, and she fears his disapproval. She quickly tucks a stray strand of hair behind her ear, hoping he won't notice the mistake on the price tag she just stuck on.

I bet she has some major insecurities going on. If I were her boss, I’d totally call her out for that little slip-up. Like, seriously, what was she thinking? I mean, come on, she probably has way too high of standards for herself anyway. But nope, she still manages to mess things up. Now she’s basically begging for criticism from everyone around her. This situation is just a perfect example of how people are always trying to hide their true selves and hide behind these masks they think will make them look better. It’s so sad, actually – she just wants to fit in so badly, but instead, she ends up making everyone else uncomfortable with her super-stiff demeanor. Poor thing doesn’t stand a chance here; this situation is just one big example of how humans tend to overthink everything and end up being way too hard on themselves.

Triggering Event: She glanced at her phone, the screen displaying a missed call from her mother. It had rung while she was painting, lost in her art as usual. The canvas was now a chaotic mess of colors, mirroring her growing guilt. She hadn't returned her mother's calls in days, too absorbed in her latest exhibition to notice time slipping away.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, why did you have to go and paint today? Did you think it would be a good idea to ignore your mom for three days straight? Now you're sitting here with no one to talk to but me, and I'm just trying to get some work done. You're so caught up in your own world that you don't even realize how much pain you've caused. Your mother is worried sick about you, and she's probably been calling every five minutes. But all you care about is your stupid painting. It's like you're oblivious to everything else going on around you.

A familiar worry began to knot in her stomach. What if something had happened? Her mind raced with worst-case scenarios as the minutes ticked by.

Triggering Event: She sat alone in her empty classroom after school, grading papers by the fading light. As she placed a checkmark next to the last student's name, a soft rustle echoed through the silent room. A small, forgotten note fluttered from between two desks, landing at her feet. Picking it up, she recognized the handwriting of one of her students, a boy who had recently lost his mother. The note read, "I wish I could ask Mom about my science project." She felt tears welling up, her heart heavy with sadness for him and for herself, another year passing without someone to share her life with.
Generated Assessment: She'd always wondered what would happen if she got married first. Would she have been able to give birth then? Or maybe even sooner? Her mind was constantly racing with scenarios where she became pregnant before her wedding day. It seemed like every time she thought about it, she imagined a different outcome. Sometimes, she pictured giving birth during her honeymoon, other times, she envisioned an unexpected pregnancy while still living with her parents. But here’s the thing: whenever she tried to think about how this might affect her relationship with her husband-to-be, she found herself stuck in these hypothetical loops. What if he didn’t want kids? What if she couldn’t handle being a mom? These thoughts swirled around, making her feel anxious and unsure. It wasn't until she started noticing that her anxiety was affecting her relationships—specifically, her friendship—that she realized just how much this thinking was holding her back. She began to wonder if her constant questioning was causing tension between them. Was it really worth considering all those possibilities, especially when they weren’t likely to happen? Still, the fear lingered, and she found herself overthinking everything. Every conversation with her friend turned into an interrogation of her own insecurities. So many questions ran through her mind, each one leading down a rabbit hole of worst-case scenarios. And no matter how hard she tried to focus on the present, her mind kept spiraling into those endless "whats" – wondering what if she had done things differently,

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He walked home from another late shift, the weight of his uniform and the night's events heavier than usual. The house felt too quiet, too empty. He paused at the door, dreading the echo of silence inside. It was three years today since she'd left him, not by choice, but he still couldn't bring himself to change the date on their wedding photo in the hallway. He sat alone at the kitchen table, her favorite chair mockingly vacant across from him. The clock ticked loudly, each second a reminder of time moving on without her. He picked up his phone to call someone, anyone, but put it down again. No one understood. Not really. He poured himself a drink instead, the clink of glass against counter echoing in the silence. As he took his first sip, he heard it - her laughter, soft and familiar, drifting from the hallway. His heart leapt, only to plummet as reality set in. It was just the wind, whistling through the cracked window she'd always meant to fix. He sighed, rubbing at the ache in his chest, and took another drink. Another night alone with her ghost.
